article.title: Characterization of metagenome-assembled genomes from the International Space Station

funding.text: 2012 Space Biology NNH12ZTT001N grant no. 19-12829-26 under Task Order NNN13D111T award to KV

article.abstract: Several investigations on the microbial diversity and functional properties of the International Space Station (ISS) environment were carried out to understand the influence of spaceflight conditions on the microbial population.

sections.introduction: Since the publication of the first metagenome-assembled genome (MAG) in 2004 [1], MAGs have been used to confirm genomic data for taxonomic identification of uncultivated microorganisms, metabolic profiling, microbiome dynamics, and host-microbe relationships [2].
sections.methods: Data used for this study were acquired from the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) Short Read Archive under the bio-project number PRJNA438545.
sections.results: Out of the 42 ISS metagenomes submitted at NCBI, only PMA-treated metagenomes (n = 21) representing the viable/intact cells were used for generating bacterial MAGs.
sections.discussion: The common gene-based resistance phenomenon noticed in this study suggests that SNP changes in MAGs and ISS genomes might be an adaptation strategy in AMR and biofilm formation in microbes.

article.insights_summary: Good quality bacterial and fungal metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were generated from International Space Station (ISS) environmental samples, and functional properties were predicted.
article.acknowledgments: The authors declare no competing interests.
